rajawali.materials.textures

Class TextureManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • rajawali.renderer.AFrameTask
      • rajawali.materials.AResourceManager
        • rajawali.materials.textures.TextureManager

  • public final class TextureManager
extends AResourceManager
    A singleton class that keeps track of all textures used by the application. All textures will be restored when the OpenGL context is being recreated. This however needs to be indicated by setting ATexture.shouldRecycle(boolean) to true (which is the default). It will then keep a reference to the Bitmap which means the application will take up more memory.

    The advantage of storing the Bitmap in memory is that it the texture can quickly be recovered when the context is restored.

    Author:
    dennis.ippel

      • reload

        public void reload()
        Restores all textures that are managed by the TextureManager. All textures will be restored when the OpenGL context is being recreated. This however needs to be indicated by setting ATexture.shouldRecycle(boolean) to true (which is the default). It will then keep a reference to the Bitmap which means the application will take up more memory.

        The advantage of storing the Bitmap in memory is that it the texture can quickly be recovered when the context is restored.

      • taskReload

        public void taskReload()
        Restores all textures that are managed by the TextureManager. This should only be called by RajawaliRender.

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Completely resets the TextureManager. Disposes the Bitmaps and removes all references.

      • taskReset

        public void taskReset()
        Completely resets the TextureManager. This should only be called by RajawaliRender.

      • taskReset

        public void taskReset(RajawaliRenderer renderer)
        Completely resets the TextureManager. This should only be called by RajawaliRender.
        Parameters:
        renderer -
